  1. Keeping It Simple

Keeping It Simple

The new bubble curtain at the Esquimalt Graving Dock is saving hundreds of salmon and keeping shipyards running smoothly.

The PWGSC-owned dock in Victoria, BC, is a world-class water vessel repair facility. At over 350 metres long (the length of three football fields) and nearly 50 metres wide, it is wider than the Panama Canal and can accommodate 90 per-cent of existing ocean vessels. PWGSC leases space to private shipyards, which work on BC Ferries, cruise ships, and other vessels. About 70 ships come in and out every year.

Unwanted Visitors

Up until recently, the challenge was the uninvited guests that came in with the ships when they entered the dock. When the water was drained, dozens of fish and the odd seal were being trapped inside, stranded on the dock floor.

Seals had to be coaxed into a first aid basket, and lifted by a crane over the dock walls to be released back into the ocean.

"It was quite an ordeal getting them out," says Daryl Lawes, PWGSC Environmental Coordinator, Environmental Services Directorate in Victoria.

"They would bite and snap at the brooms used, and up to six dock employees would be needed to rescue them."

The bigger problem was the fish. Mr. Lawes says that a local anglers association was releasing salmon into the nearby marina, and fish restoration efforts in the harbour and adjacent rivers led to a significant increase in fish activity. The grey graving dock simply looked like a river mouth to the salmon, and attracted them in droves.

After the dock water was pumped out, up to 20 employees in gumboots would run around the dock floor with nets, scooping up fish. Ship owners stood by and waited, unhappy that they were losing precious dock time and that sometimes hundreds of repair personnel were forced to remain idle.

It came to a head about a year and a half ago when a ship docked at around 11:30 p.m. When the water was pumped out, almost 150 salmon — at 20 to 25 kilos each — were splashing on the dock floor.

PWGSC Dock Operator Bill Anderson recalls being told to put his hipwaders on. "There were fish everywhere," he says. "I've never seen so many. We were told to try to save the female coho salmon and we were there until four in the morning with all the repair work on hold."

Caption: Before the installation of the bubble curtain, seals would often find their way into the Esquimalt Graving Dock. Here, a visitor is gently escorted out of the dock before ship repairs begin.

A Creative Answer

Caption: A black pipe down the wall and a white pipe along the bottom of the Esquimalt Graving Dock release a curtain of air bubbles that prevent seals and fish from entering the dock with ships.

Mr. Anderson, who has a background in the pipeline industry, was asked to come up with a solution. His research revealed a bubble curtain that was used at some fish hatcheries and dams, and he adapted the concept for the graving dock. A long pipe was fitted to run down the 25 metre walls and across the floor. A series of holes, about 60 centimetres apart, was drilled into the pipes and a pressure gauge fitted on top.

Mr. Anderson said the project was an experiment and it earned him the nickname "Bubble Boy." "I got teased a lot. People told me they weren't sure it was going to work. I would answer, 'Neither am I.' "

But it did. As a ship approached, the turn of a handle forced air through the small holes, producing a curtain of bubbles. The salmon turned away from it and the seals, curious by nature, were attracted by the oddity, but did not venture past it.

Mr. Lawes says they haven't had any complaints since they introduced the curtain. He says the real test will come this fall during spawning season when salmon return to the area, but he remains optimistic. And the final price tag for the cost-saving solution was only $700.

"This is a real success," says Mr. Lawes. "Everyone is pleased. Sometimes the best solutions are the simplest."
